SUMMARY: transcription factor NhaR, for Na+/H+ antiporter Regulator, is dependent on Na+ and it controls transcription of gene involved in adaptation to Na+ and alkaline pH [1316901, 8168494, 8144493, 10207920, 9312050, 7823039, 8017942, 7823039] response to adverse conditions [12867437, 11577158] and biofilm formation [16997959, 18445167]. This regulator belongs to LysR family. NhaR is composed of two domains: amino-terminal domain, which contains DNA-binding region, and carboxy-terminal domain, which is possibly responsible for inducer binding [3413113]. In systematic studies of oligomerization, it was shown that some members of LysR family, like NhaR, interact with or members of family to form heterodimers, but physiological significance of this is unknown [21187915]. binding targets for NhaR are 17 nucleotides long. Each dimer binds to one of se conserved sequences. lengths of degenerate binding sites of NhaR were defined according to matrix shown for this regulator in database RegPrecise, which contains matrices generated from alignments of orthologous regions [19884135].
